additionalTextInformation.text:
Heinrich the Devout was born in Dresden in 1473 as the youngest son of Albrecht III of Saxony. It was not until 1505, through the administrative bodies of Freiberg and Wolkenstein, that he obtained his own small dominion in the middle of the Albertine territory governed by his brother Georg. Schloss Freiberg became his residence. He associated with artisans and miners, listened to reports of foreign warfare and had a large collection of  small arms and guns. In 1512 Heinrich married Katharina of Mecklenburg, who over the years won him over to the new doctrine. The pair employed a lutheran court chaplain and had the German mass read in the palace of Freiberg (1564). Despite the opposition of his catholic brother, the Freiberg clergy of the old faith, the bishop of Meißen and the protesting nobility Heinrich (1537) introduced the Reformation into his own territory and after the death of his brother into the rest of the Albertine territorial state acquired by him. At the same time together with his son Moritz he signed the prime contract of the Schmalkaldic league. In 1541 Heinrich died in Dresden, shortly after Moritz's appointment to co-regent. 

[Cat. Kassel 1997, 77]

pageContext.description:
The painting in Kassel shows the duke wearing simple, unembellished clothes. He wears a fur-lined robe with broad lapels and a beret with a brim covering his forehead and folded back at the sides. The main features of his face are recorded with a few distinctive lines. The light falling on the significant forms make them stand out clearly. [...] The face radiates energy and authority. The wrinkles between the eyebrows and the fixed gaze into the far distance contribute to this. The compact shape of the beret and the beard with their matching, diagonally ascending outlines make the head appear broader and more imposing. On the right side above the sitter's shoulder a mountain ridge is visible. Behind this is an expansive sky in which the hues characteristic of numerous other Cranach paintings are employed. These consist of yellow at the bottom which merges with pink and then blue. 

[Cat. Kassel 1997, 79-80]

pageContext.markings:
Verso:
- bottom left:
in red paint '1223' (Inventory number from the ll. Supplement to inventory of 1749)

Reverse of the panel: 
- in red paint the inventory number of the II. Supplements '1223' 
- a label from the Staatl. Museen Kassel, 20th century
- in white chalk, in part illegible inscription, among others '2. Supplement'

- at the right edge:
remnants of an english newspaper from 1876 

[Cat. Kassel 1997, 77]

metadata.title: Portrait of Duke Heinrich the Devout of Saxony (1473-1541)

pageContext.provenance:
- the portrait may have passed into the estate of the landgrave of Hesse shortly after its production: Heinrich the Devout was an uncle of Christine of Saxony who was espoused to Philipp
- or the panel may have been given to Heinrich's granddaughter, Anna of Saxony (1544-1577), when she married William of Orange (1561), and after her death(1584) could have been passed on from her sister Catharine of Nassau (d. 1624) to Catherine Belgica (d. 1648) and then through one of their two daughters, Amalie Elisabeth or Catharine Juliane may have entered the estate of the landgrave of Hesse in Kassel 

[Cat. Kassel 1997, 77]

restorationSurveys.remarks:

[Curatorial files, Gemäldegalerie Alte Meister Kassel]

restorationSurveys.overallAnalysis:
- the garments including the fur-collar are almost completely overpainted 
- there is a large area of overpaint on the hilltop and above it in the sky, and smaller areas over the landscape. 

[Cat. Kassel 1997, 77]
